quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 10 Quiz 7
quiz.subtitle: 10.7: Gibbs Free Energy
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: The criterion for spontaneity and the Gibbs equation

questions.question: Which equation defines the change in Gibbs free energy ($\Delta G$) for a system at constant temperature and pressure?
questions.explanation: The Gibbs equation combines enthalpy, temperature, and entropy to determine the energy available to do useful work.

questions.question: For a process to be spontaneous at constant temperature and pressure, the change in Gibbs free energy ($\Delta G$) must be:
questions.explanation: A negative $\Delta G$ indicates that the process is thermodynamically favorable and can occur without continuous external energy input.

questions.question: If a reaction is at equilibrium, what is the value of $\Delta G$?
questions.explanation: At equilibrium, there is no net driving force for the reaction in either direction, so the free energy change is zero.

questions.question: A reaction has a negative $\Delta H$ and a positive $\Delta S$. Under what conditions is this reaction spontaneous?
options: It is spontaneous at all temperatures.
It is only spontaneous at high temperatures.
It is only spontaneous at low temperatures.
questions.explanation: When $\Delta H$ is negative and $\Delta S$ is positive, both terms in the Gibbs equation ($\Delta H$ and $-T\Delta S$) are negative, making $\Delta G$ always negative.

questions.question: What is the physical meaning of the 'free' in Gibbs free energy?
options: Energy available to do useful work.
Energy that is gained for no cost.
Energy that is released as light.
Energy that is independent of pressure.
questions.explanation: Free energy represents the portion of the total enthalpy change that is not 'lost' to entropy and can be used for work.

questions.question: A reaction has a positive $\Delta H$ and a positive $\Delta S$. When does this reaction become spontaneous?
questions.explanation: The $-T\Delta S$ term must be large enough to overcome the positive $\Delta H$. This happens when $T$ is high.

questions.question: What is the standard state temperature usually used for $\Delta G^{\circ}$ calculations in textbooks?
questions.explanation: Standard conditions are defined as 298 K ($25$Â°C) and 1 atm pressure.

questions.question: If $\Delta G$ for a process is positive, the process is said to be:
questions.explanation: A positive $\Delta G$ means the process is endergonic and requires work to be done on the system to proceed.

questions.question: Which of the following is true for a reaction where $\Delta H > 0$ and $\Delta S < 0$?
options: The reaction is non-spontaneous at all temperatures.
The reaction is spontaneous at all temperatures.
The reaction is spontaneous only at low temperatures.
The reaction is spontaneous only at high temperatures.
questions.explanation: Both terms ($+\Delta H$ and $-T(-\Delta S)$) are positive, so $\Delta G$ will always be positive.

questions.question: Does a spontaneous reaction ($\Delta G < 0$) necessarily occur quickly?
options: No, $\Delta G$ only tells us about the direction of the reaction, not the rate.
Yes, all spontaneous reactions are fast.
No, but it will occur instantly if a catalyst is added.
Yes, if the temperature is above 298 K.
questions.explanation: Spontaneity is a thermodynamic property. The speed of the reaction depends on kinetics (activation energy).

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have mastered the logic of free energy and spontaneity.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. You understand how enthalpy and entropy compete.
scoreMessages.50: Satisfactory. Review the four combinations of $\Delta H$ and $\Delta S$ signs.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on the Gibbs equation: $\Delta G = \Delta H - T\Delta S$.
